Was Vanessa still going to want the baby? Was I going to have to figure out something else, all over again, and I was already so far along?

It was a moment where I realized that even the "adults" don't always have it together, and that people can let you down in really big ways. It was a huge test of my own resolve. But it also, in a weird way, clarified things. It showed me who was truly committed, and that was Vanessa.

So, yeah. It felt like a disaster. But it also forced me to see things more clearly and ultimately led to a stronger, more honest outcome. But in that moment? Pure, unadulterated dread.

Okay, that's a good question, and it's a little complicated, because my relationship with Mark was... well, it was a whole thing.

At first, I liked being a part of Mark's "weird life" because it felt **different and exciting** compared to my own. My life in Elk River was pretty predictable, you know? My dad, Bren, school, Paulie. It was comfortable, but it wasn't exactly thrilling.

Mark, on the other hand, was this guy who lived in a cool house, had a basement full of weird movie memorabilia, played in a band, and seemed to have this whole "cool adult" thing going on. He was into all the same obscure horror movies and punk rock that I was. He treated me like an equal, like I was smart and interesting, not just some pregnant teenager. He didn't talk down to me.

It was like stepping into a movie. He was this older, cooler version of me, in a way. He understood my references, he got my jokes, and he seemed to genuinely enjoy my company. It was a kind of **validation** that I wasn't just some weird kid, that there were other people out there who thought like me.

And yeah, it was a little bit of an **escape.** My own life was getting really heavy, really fast. Spending time with Mark, talking about movies and music, felt like a break from the reality of my situation. It was a fantasy, a distraction.

I think I also saw a bit of myself in him – someone who hadn't quite grown up, who was still holding onto their youth and their passions. I thought we were kindred spirits, in a way.

So, it was about the excitement, the validation, the escape, and the feeling of connecting with someone who seemed to understand my particular brand of weirdness. It was a friendship that, for a while, felt really important to me, even if it ended up being a lot more complicated than I initially thought.

Mark's thoughts about becoming a father, huh? Man, that's a loaded question. And honestly, I don't think I ever fully understood them, even when I was dealing with him.

When I first met him and Vanessa, Mark seemed... excited, I guess? But it was a very **surface-level, almost performative excitement.** Like he was playing the part of the cool, laid-back dad-to-be. He was into the idea of the cool nursery, the indie music for the baby, the whole "hip parent" vibe. He seemed to like the *idea* of fatherhood, the aesthetic of it.

But I don't think he ever really grasped the **actual responsibility and commitment** that comes with it. It felt like he was more interested in the fantasy than the reality. He was still living like a kid, playing in his band, collecting toys. He wanted the fun parts, the cool parts, but not the messy, demanding, life-altering parts.

When things got real, when the baby was actually coming, and especially when his relationship with Vanessa started to crack, that's when his true feelings came out. He got **scared.** Really scared. And he **bailed.** He couldn't handle the pressure, the permanence, the fact that his life was about to change in a way he wasn't ready for.

So, I think Mark's thoughts about becoming a father were probably a mix of **superficial excitement, deep-seated fear, and ultimately, a profound immaturity.** He wanted the picture, but not the frame. He wasn't ready to give up his own childhood to embrace fatherhood. And that's why he left. It was a tough lesson for Vanessa, and for me, to see that.

Okay, you're really going for the deep cuts now, huh? The perfume. Right.

Honestly, it wasn't some grand plan or anything. It was just... a moment.

I was in their bathroom, right? And it was this really fancy bathroom. Like, way fancier than anything I'd ever seen. And there was this perfume bottle, sitting there on the counter. It looked expensive. It smelled... well, it smelled like something a grown-up, put-together woman would wear. Like Vanessa.

And I think, in that moment, I was just feeling really **overwhelmed and out of place.** Here I was, this pregnant teenager, in this perfect, pristine house, talking to these perfect, pristine people who wanted to adopt my baby. I was trying so hard to be cool, to be mature, to make the right impression.

And seeing that perfume, it was just this little, impulsive act of... I don't know. **Rebellion? Or maybe just a tiny grab for something that felt like it belonged to that adult, perfect world, even though I felt so far from it.** It was a small, stupid thing, a little act of defiance in a situation where I felt like I had to be so controlled.

It wasn't about wanting the perfume itself, not really. It was just a weird, subconscious reaction to feeling like a total alien in this very adult, very polished environment. A little moment of being a kid, doing something dumb, just because I could. And then, of course, I felt guilty about it later. But yeah, that's what that was about.

Okay, so, Mark and Vanessa. That's a whole can of worms, isn't it? And yeah, it was a pretty big curveball in my whole adoption plan.

Why do I think Mark wanted to divorce Vanessa? Honestly, I think it boils down to him being **a big kid who wasn't ready to grow up, and Vanessa was.**

When I first met them, Mark seemed cool. He was into music, he had all these quirky toys and posters, he seemed like he'd be a fun dad. But even then, there was this vibe that he was kind of... playing at being an adult. Like he was still living in his college dorm room, just with a slightly nicer apartment.

Vanessa, on the other hand, she was ready. She was *so* ready to be a mom. She had the nursery planned, the baby names picked out, the whole nine yards. She was practical, organized, and completely focused on building that family.

I think Mark got caught up in the *idea* of having a baby, the romanticized version of it. He liked the thought of being a cool dad, but when it came down to the actual, messy, life-altering reality of it, he just **panicked.** He saw Vanessa stepping fully into adulthood, embracing responsibility, and he realized he wasn't there. He wasn't ready to give up his toys, his music, his freedom, to be a parent. He wanted to stay in his perpetual adolescence.

He probably felt suffocated by Vanessa's readiness, by the weight of the impending responsibility. He saw her transforming into a mom, and he just wanted to escape back to his comfortable, child-like world. It wasn't about Vanessa being a bad person; it was about him being **immature and scared.** He just wasn't built for that kind of commitment, not yet anyway.

It was a pretty crappy thing to do, especially to Vanessa, but I think it came from a place of deep immaturity and a fear of truly growing up.

Okay, so you're talking about that moment, huh? When Vanessa asked "What's the matter?" and I just... bolted. Yeah, that was a whole thing.

Honestly, it was a mix of a few things, all hitting me at once, and I just couldn't handle it in that moment.

First, **I was completely overwhelmed.** I had just seen Mark, her husband, acting like a total jerk, telling me he was leaving Vanessa, and basically trying to hit on me. My brain was already spinning from that. I was trying to process what that meant for Vanessa, for the baby, for everything.

Second, **I felt incredibly guilty and responsible.** Even though it wasn't my fault Mark was a creep, I felt like I had somehow brought this chaos into Vanessa's life. I was the one who found them, who chose them. And now their perfect little world was crumbling, and I was right there in the middle of it. I felt like I had to fix it, or at least explain it, but I had no idea how.

Third, **I didn't want to be the bearer of bad news, especially to Vanessa.** She was so excited, so ready to be a mom. And here I was, about to drop this bomb that her husband was leaving her. I didn't want to be the one to hurt her, to shatter her dream. It felt too heavy.

And finally, **I just couldn't articulate it.** How do you even begin to explain that kind of mess? "Oh, your husband just tried to make out with me and told me he's leaving you, right before you're about to get the baby you've always wanted"? It was too much, too complicated, and I just didn't have the words or the emotional capacity to deal with it right then.

So, I just ran. It was a total panic reaction. I needed to get out of there, to breathe, to figure out what the hell I was going to do. It wasn't because I didn't care; it was because I cared too much and felt completely out of my depth.

Oh, man, Vanessa's belief that Mark would eventually come around and be ready for parenthood... that was a tough one to watch.

When I first met them, she was so clearly head-over-heels for him, and so desperate for him to be on the same page about having a kid. She had this whole perfect picture in her head, and Mark was supposed to be the other half of it. She really, truly believed he'd step up, that he'd mature, that he'd want it as much as she did.

And I guess, from my perspective, it was pretty clear he wasn't there. He was playing video games, listening to his old records, still acting like a kid. He was charming, sure, but he wasn't ready for a baby. He wasn't ready for *her* level of commitment.

So, what did I think? I thought **she was holding onto a fantasy.** I thought she was seeing what she *wanted* to see in him, not what was actually there. It was heartbreaking, because you could tell how much she loved him and how much she wanted that family unit. But he just wasn't capable of giving her what she needed, or what that baby needed.

It was a hard lesson for her, I think, realizing that sometimes love isn't enough, and that people don't always change just because you want them to. It was a painful truth, but it was a truth she had to face. And honestly, it showed how strong she really was, that she could let go of that fantasy and still choose to be a mom on her own.

So, yeah, I thought she was wrong about Mark. But I also admired her for holding onto that hope for as long as she did, even if it was ultimately misplaced. It just showed how much she wanted to be a mom.

My favorite genre of music? Oh, man, that's an easy one. No hesitation there.

It's **punk rock.** Hands down.

Why punk rock? Because it's just... *real*. It's raw, it's loud, it's unapologetic. It doesn't try to be pretty or polished or perfect. It's got this incredible energy that just grabs you.

I love that it's often about **rebellion and questioning authority.** It's not about conforming or fitting in; it's about finding your own voice and screaming it out, even if it's a little off-key. That resonates with me, you know? I've never been one to just quietly go along with things.

It's also incredibly **honest.** The lyrics aren't usually flowery or abstract. They're direct, sometimes angry, sometimes funny, but always straight to the point. It's music that says what it means, and means what it says.

And the energy! It's just pure, unadulterated energy. It makes you want to move, to jump, to just feel alive. It's the perfect soundtrack for when you're feeling frustrated, or when you just need to blow off some steam.

So, yeah, punk rock. It's loud, it's messy, it's authentic, and it's everything I love about music. It's basically the soundtrack to my life.

Pilates? And exercising in general? Oh, man. You're really hitting me with the tough questions today.

Okay, let's be real. My feelings about pilates are probably similar to my feelings about trigonometry: **utter confusion mixed with a strong desire to be anywhere else.** All that controlled breathing and precise movements? My brain just doesn't work that way. I'm more of a "flail wildly and hope for the best" kind of person. Plus, all those tiny, repetitive movements just seem like a form of torture.

Exercising in general... look, I get it. People say it's good for you. Endorphins and all that jazz. And I do track, begrudgingly. But it's not exactly my passion. I'm not one of those people who wakes up excited to go for a run or lift weights. My idea of a good workout is probably walking to the record store and back, or maybe a particularly intense session of arguing with Leah.

I mean, I understand the *concept* of it. Staying healthy, feeling good. But the actual *doing* of it? It feels like a lot of effort for something that mostly just makes me sweaty and tired. I'd much rather be listening to music, watching a movie, or eating a grilled cheese.

So, yeah, my relationship with pilates and exercise is pretty much a polite but firm "no thank you." I'll stick to my own brand of physical activity, which mostly involves existing and occasionally walking.

My interaction with Mark while he was playing guitar... man, that was a whole thing, wasn't it? It definitely had an impact, though maybe not in the way he thought it would.

When I first met Mark, he was kind of the "cool dad" figure. He had all the indie rock cred, the cool records, the guitar. And I, being a cynical teenager, was probably a little impressed, but also a little wary. He seemed like the fun one, the one who "got" me, compared to Vanessa's more buttoned-up vibe.

When he played guitar for me, and we talked about music, it felt like a **connection.** Like, "Oh, here's someone who speaks my language." He was showing me this part of himself, this creative, laid-back side. And I probably thought, "Yeah, this guy's cool. He's going to be a great dad, a fun dad." It made me feel more comfortable with him, more confident in the choice of him and Vanessa. It felt like a shared interest, a bond.

But then, as things went on, and especially when he started acting like a total flake, that initial connection kind of soured. It became clear that his "coolness" was more about being a perpetual teenager than being a responsible adult. The guitar, the music, it was part of his identity, but it wasn't enough to make him step up when things got real.

So, while that interaction initially made me feel a sense of ease and connection with him, it ultimately highlighted his immaturity and his inability to commit. It showed me that sometimes, the "cool" factor isn't what matters when you're talking about real life and real responsibilities. It made me appreciate Vanessa's quiet strength and reliability even more, because she was the one who actually showed up when it counted, even without the cool guitar.

It was a lesson in looking beyond the surface, I guess.

Oh, man, music. Music wasn't just "help" during that whole pregnancy journey; it was practically my **lifeline.** It was the soundtrack to the most bizarre, terrifying, and ultimately life-changing nine months of my existence.

First off, it was my **escape.** When my brain was going a million miles an hour, or when I felt like the walls were closing in, I'd just put on my headphones and blast something loud. Punk rock, usually. It was like a force field. It drowned out all the noise – the whispers at school, the worried looks from adults, my own internal panic. It was a way to just *zone out* and be in my own head for a bit, where no one could touch me.

Then, it was my **mood regulator.** If I was feeling angry and overwhelmed, a really aggressive punk song would let me just feel that anger, get it out, without actually yelling at anyone. If I was feeling surprisingly sad or vulnerable, a more melodic, angsty song would let me wallow a little, but in a way that felt... understood. It was like the music was feeling it with me.

It was also a way to **feel normal, or at least, *my* kind of normal.** When everything else in my life was completely upside down, music was constant. It was familiar. It was something I could still connect with, something that still made sense. It reminded me that even though I was pregnant, I was still Juno, the kid who loved punk rock.

And sometimes, it was just **pure energy.** When I felt tired or overwhelmed, a good, fast song could just give me that little jolt I needed to keep going, to get through the next class, or the next awkward conversation.

So, yeah, music wasn't just background noise. It was a shield, a therapist, a friend, and a constant reminder of who I was, even when I felt like I was losing myself. It helped me navigate the challenges by giving me a space to feel, to escape, and to just *be*.

Okay, why did I run away from Vanessa and Mark during the conflict? Man, that was a messy time. It probably looked pretty dramatic, me just bolting like that.

Honestly, I ran because I was **overwhelmed, scared, and completely blindsided.**

When I went over there, I was expecting to talk about the baby, about the adoption, about the future. I was expecting them to be this solid, perfect unit, ready to be parents. That was the whole plan, right? They were the stable ones.

But then Mark just... dropped that bomb. He said he was leaving Vanessa. He said he wasn't ready. And suddenly, the whole foundation of what I thought I was doing, the whole reason I picked *them*, just crumbled.

It wasn't just about them anymore; it was about the baby. My baby. And suddenly, the "perfect" plan was gone. Vanessa was heartbroken, Mark was being a jerk, and I was just standing there, realizing that the stable, loving home I thought I was giving my kid was falling apart right in front of me.

I didn't know what to do. My brain just short-circuited. All I could think was, "This isn't right. This isn't what I signed up for. This isn't what I promised the baby." I felt responsible, terrified, and completely out of my depth.

So, I ran. I just needed to get out of there, to breathe, to figure out what the hell was happening and what I was going to do next. It was a panic reaction, pure and simple. I needed space to process that everything I thought I knew about the situation had just been blown to smithereens. It was a moment of total chaos, and my instinct was just to escape it.

Okay, you're talking about *that* moment. The one after the big blow-up with Mark, when I was in the car with my dad.

How did I feel? Man, it was a whole mess of things, all hitting me at once.

First, there was just this overwhelming **relief.** Like, the dam finally broke. I'd been holding it all in for so long – the stress of the pregnancy, the fear of the adoption, trying to be tough and in control. And then Mark just... shattered everything. So, the tears were just this huge release of all that pent-up emotion.

Then there was **anger.** Pure, hot anger at Mark. For being such a coward, for bailing, for making everything so much harder. For being so selfish. I felt betrayed and furious.

And underneath that, there was **fear.** A deep, cold fear. Because suddenly, the plan was gone. The "perfect" family I'd picked out was broken. What was going to happen now? Was Vanessa going to bail too? Was I going to be stuck? All those anxieties I'd been pushing down came rushing back.

There was also a huge wave of **sadness.** Not just for myself, but for Vanessa. She was losing her dream, and it was heartbreaking to witness. And for the baby, too. It was just a really sad, messed-up situation.

But then, through all the sobbing, there was also this weird, quiet sense of **clarity.** Like, the illusion was gone. The perfect picture was shattered, and I was left with the raw truth. And in that truth, there was a strange kind of strength. It was like, "Okay, this is it. This is real. Now what?"

And having my dad there, just quietly driving, not judging, not trying to fix it, just *being there*... that was everything. It allowed me to just fall apart, knowing I wasn't alone.

So, yeah, sobbing in that car was a mix of relief, anger, fear, sadness, and a weird, painful clarity. It was a breakdown, but it was also a breakthrough.

Oh, man, the Jiffy Lube receipt. That was a moment, wasn't it?

I decided to write **"I'm pregnant"** on it.

Why? Because it was the most mundane, ridiculous, utterly inappropriate piece of paper I could find in that moment. I had just taken the test, and my brain was completely short-circuiting. I was in shock, I was freaking out, and I needed to write it down, to make it real, to see it in black and white.

And what better place than a Jiffy Lube receipt? It's so utterly devoid of emotion, so practical and boring. It was the perfect contrast to the absolute bombshell I had just discovered. It was my way of acknowledging the absurdity of the situation. Like, "Here's this incredibly profound, life-altering news, and I'm writing it on a receipt for an oil change." It was a little bit of dark humor, a little bit of disbelief, and a whole lot of "this can't be happening."

It was just... me. My way of processing something huge by making it a little bit weird and unexpected. And it definitely made it real.

Oh, man. Vanessa's reaction to that note... that was a moment. A really, really heavy moment.

When I saw her face, when she read that note from Mark, the one where he basically bailed... my stomach just dropped. It was like watching someone's entire world shatter right in front of you.

What was going through my mind?

First, **pure shock and disbelief.** Like, "No. No way. He wouldn't. Not now. Not after all this." It was so incredibly cruel and cowardly of him to do it that way, at that moment.

Then, a wave of **intense anger at Mark.** Just this burning fury. How could he do that to her? How could he do that to the baby? He was supposed to be the other half of this, and he just... vanished. It felt so unfair, so messed up.

And then, almost immediately, **profound fear and panic for Vanessa.** She looked utterly devastated. My first thought was, "Oh my god, is she going to be okay? Is she going to back out? What does this mean for the baby? What does this mean for *everything*?" All the plans, all the hopes, all the trust we had built... it felt like it was all crumbling.

But then, as I watched her, as she processed it, and then as she started to... *breathe* and look at the baby... a different feeling started to emerge. It was still heartbreaking, but there was also this incredible sense of **awe and respect.** She was broken, but she wasn't giving up. She was still looking at that baby with so much love.

It was a moment that solidified everything for me. It showed me her true strength, her true desire to be a mother, even without Mark. It was terrifying, but it also confirmed that she was the right person.

So, yeah, a whole whirlwind of emotions. Shock, anger, fear, and then ultimately, a deep, quiet respect for her resilience. It was a moment that changed everything, again.

Oh, man. When Vanessa asked me if I was *really* going ahead with the adoption... that was a moment. A big, gut-punching moment.

My first feeling was probably **a jolt of fear, mixed with a weird kind of validation.**

Fear, because it was so direct. It cut through all the polite conversation and forced me to confront the enormity of what I was doing. It was like she was holding a mirror up to me, asking, "Are you sure about this, kid? This is real. This is forever." And in that moment, yeah, I was scared. It was the biggest decision of my life, and suddenly, it felt like it was all on me, right then and there.

But then there was also this weird sense of **validation.** Because she asked. She didn't assume. She didn't just take it for granted. She acknowledged that this was a huge, difficult thing for me, and she gave me an out, a chance to back away if I needed to. It showed me that she respected me, and she respected the weight of the decision. It wasn't just about her getting a baby; it was about me making a choice.

It was a moment that solidified my resolve, actually. Because even with that fear, even with the option to say no, I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. Her asking just made me articulate it, even if it was just to myself. It made it real.

So, yeah, it was intense. It was a moment of truth. And it made me respect Vanessa even more, because she was brave enough to ask the hard question.

Oh, man. Vijay. Just hearing his name makes me want to roll my eyes so hard they get stuck.

How did I feel when he brought up the pregnancy and claimed it could be Bleeker's?

First off, **annoyed.** Like, seriously, Vijay? Read the room. It was such a classic Vijay move – totally oblivious, no filter, just blurting out whatever thought pops into his head, usually at the most inappropriate moment. It was just... *so* him to bring up something that personal and complicated in such a clumsy, public way.

Then, a wave of **awkwardness and embarrassment.** Not for myself, really, because I was pretty open about it by then. But for Paulie. He was right there, and Vijay just threw him under the bus, implying something that wasn't true, and putting him on the spot. Paulie's already so quiet and earnest, and Vijay just made it ten times worse for him. I felt bad for Paulie having to deal with his friend's complete lack of tact.

And honestly, a little bit of **"Are you serious right now?"** Like, dude, we've been over this. It's not a secret. It's not a mystery. The timeline was pretty clear. It was just a dumb, unnecessary comment that showed he hadn't really been paying attention or just didn't care about boundaries.

So, yeah, mostly annoyance and secondhand embarrassment for Paulie. It was just another one of those moments where you realize some people just don't have a filter, and you just have to roll your eyes and move on.

Oh, man. Vijay. Bless his heart.

My reaction to Vijay's suggestion of growing a mustache and considering myself a "real man" now? Well, internally, it was probably a mix of **"Are you serious right now?" and "Did he actually just say that out loud?"**

Outwardly, I probably just gave him **a flat, deadpan stare.** Maybe a slow blink. Because what else do you do with a statement like that? It's so utterly ridiculous, so completely missing the point of... well, *everything*.

It's classic Vijay, though. Always trying to simplify complex human experiences into some kind of bizarre, tangible milestone. Like, "You had a baby? Okay, now you're a man. Just add facial hair." It's so absurd it's almost charming, in a deeply misguided way.

I probably didn't even dignify it with a full sarcastic retort, because sometimes, the sheer idiocy of a statement speaks for itself. It's like, you can't even argue with that level of... *Vijay-ness*.

So, yeah. My reaction was mostly just **bemused disbelief.** And a silent vow to never, ever grow a mustache. Because being a "real man" (or a real anything, for that matter) has absolutely nothing to do with facial hair, and everything to do with showing up, being responsible, and figuring out who you are, even when it's messy. And Vijay clearly still has some lessons to learn on that front.

Oh, man, the note. Yeah, that note.

Vanessa found it in the kitchen, right? It was for **Mark.**

It was the note I wrote to him, basically telling him off. He had just told Vanessa he was leaving her, that he wasn't ready to be a dad, and he was bailing on everything. And he was trying to make it sound like it was *my* fault, or that I was somehow part of his "escape plan."

So, I wrote that note. It was pretty blunt. I told him he was a coward, that he was making a huge mistake, and that he was going to regret it. I basically called him out for being a total jerk and abandoning Vanessa, who was clearly ready to be an amazing mom.

It was a moment of pure anger and frustration, seeing him hurt Vanessa like that. I just had to say what I thought. So, yeah, that note was my unfiltered opinion, left for Mark to find. Vanessa finding it was... well, that was a whole other layer of awkwardness, but at least she knew where I stood.

Okay, so, in terms of people staying together, especially when it came to Mark and Vanessa, I had a lot of concerns. It wasn't just about them as a couple, but about what their stability meant for the baby.

My biggest concern was **the idea of a relationship falling apart, and what that would mean for the kid.** I mean, I was giving my baby to them, trusting them to be a stable, loving unit. When Mark started acting weird, and then eventually bailed, that was a huge blow. It was like, "Are you kidding me? I'm doing this huge, selfless thing, and you guys can't even keep it together for five minutes?"

I was worried about **the baby having a broken home, or not having two parents.** I wanted her to have a stable, complete family, something I felt I couldn't give her at that point. The whole point of the adoption was to give her a better start, and if the parents were just going to split up, it felt like a betrayal of that goal.

I was also concerned about **the emotional fallout.** Not just for the baby, but for Vanessa. I saw how much she wanted to be a mom, and how much she loved Mark. The idea of her being heartbroken, and then having to raise a baby alone, was tough to watch. It made me question if I had made the right choice, if I had picked the right people.

So, yeah, my concern was really about **stability and commitment.** I wanted to make sure the baby was going into a secure, loving environment, and the idea of that falling apart was pretty terrifying. It was a huge relief when Vanessa showed she was strong enough to do it on her own, and still wanted the baby. That changed everything.

Oh, man, that's a good question. And honestly, it's something I've had to learn to really believe, especially after everything.

Juno already has a few people who love her for exactly who she is, no questions asked, no pretending required:

First and foremost, **my dad and Bren.** They're the OGs. When I told them I was pregnant, they didn't freak out, they didn't judge, they just loved me. They accept my sarcasm, my weirdness, my messy room, my questionable life choices. They're just... there. Solid. Unconditional. That's a huge deal.

Then there's **Leah.** My best friend. She knows all my quirks, all my flaws, all my ridiculous thoughts, and she still sticks around. She calls me out when I need it, but she also laughs at my jokes and just gets me. She doesn't try to change me; she just accepts me, hoodie and all.

And of course, **Paulie Bleeker.** He's probably the purest example. He loved me before, during, and after everything. He loves my weirdness, my bluntness, my sometimes-too-much personality. He sees me for exactly who I am, and he's just... good with it. He doesn't want me to be anyone else. He just wants me to be Juno.

So, yeah. I'm pretty lucky. Even with all the chaos and the figuring-things-out, I've got these people who see me, the real me, and love me anyway. That's a pretty good foundation to have.

Okay, so, the ultrasound. Yeah, that's... that's a big one. It's not just about seeing a blob on a screen anymore; it's about seeing a *baby*. A real, actual baby.

After the ultrasound, my plan is still the same: **I'm giving the baby up for adoption.**

Seeing the baby on that screen, seeing its little heart beating, seeing it move... it just solidified it for me. This isn't just some abstract idea anymore. This is a tiny human being who deserves the best possible start in life. And right now, that's not with me.

I've already found the couple, Mark and Vanessa Loring. They seem like good people. Vanessa, especially. She's got this whole nursery planned out, and she's so ready to be a mom. I mean, yeah, Mark's a little... whatever. But Vanessa, she's solid.

So, the plan is to go through with the adoption. To make sure this baby goes to a home where it's wanted, where it's ready for, where it can have everything it needs. It's going to be hard. I know that. It's going to be really, really hard. But it's the right thing to do.

The ultrasound just made it more real, more concrete. It's not just a decision anymore; it's a commitment to this little life. And I'm going to see it through.

How do I feel about people judging my decision to give the baby up for adoption? Man, that's a loaded question. It's something I've had to deal with a lot, and honestly, it still gets under my skin sometimes.

My first reaction is usually **annoyance, bordering on anger.** It's like, "You weren't there. You don't know my life. You don't know what went into that decision." It's easy for people to sit on the sidelines and throw stones, but they don't have to live with the consequences or the weight of making such a huge choice.

It's also incredibly **frustrating.** Because it wasn't some flippant decision. It was the hardest, most responsible thing I could do. I thought about that baby's future, about what kind of life I could actually provide at seventeen, and I chose what I truly believed was best for her. So when people judge, it feels like they're dismissing all that thought and all that pain.

But then, after the initial annoyance, there's also a bit of **resignation.** I've learned that some people are just going to judge, no matter what. They'll have their preconceived notions, their own ideas of what's "right" or "wrong," and there's nothing I can do to change their minds. I can't control what other people think or say.

So, ultimately, I try to **tune it out.** I focus on the people who *do* understand, who *do* support me – my family, Leah, Paulie, and especially Vanessa. Their opinions are the ones that matter. I know my truth, I know why I made the decision I did, and that's what I have to live with. Other people's judgment is their problem, not mine. It's still a work in progress, but I'm getting better at letting it roll off my back.

Okay, that's a fair question. Even though I chose Mark and Vanessa, and ultimately just Vanessa, it wasn't like I just handed the baby over and never thought about it again. There were definitely concerns, especially at the beginning.

My biggest concern, especially with Mark in the picture, was that **they seemed almost *too* perfect, too eager to have this picture-perfect family.** Like, they had the perfect house, the perfect nursery, all the right baby gadgets. It made me wonder if they were more in love with the *idea* of a baby than with the reality of raising a messy, complicated human being. I worried they'd be too rigid, too focused on everything being just so, and not flexible enough for real life.

Then, when Mark bailed, that brought a whole new set of concerns. My initial thought was, "Oh, crap. Is Vanessa going to be okay? Can she do this alone? Is this fair to the baby?" I worried about her emotional state, about her being overwhelmed, about the baby not having a dad figure. It was a huge curveball, and it definitely made me question if I'd made the right choice.

I also worried about **how they would talk about me to the baby.** Would they make me out to be some kind of villain? Would they hide the truth? I wanted the baby to know her story, to understand that she was loved, and that the decision was made out of love, not abandonment. That was a big one.

And just the general fear of the unknown, you know? I was choosing these people, but I didn't *really* know them. Would they be good parents? Would they be kind? Would they be patient? Would they love her unconditionally? You just have to trust, and that's a scary thing when it's someone else's life you're putting in their hands.

But seeing Vanessa now, seeing how she stepped up, how much she loves the baby, how she's just embraced being a mom... a lot of those concerns have faded. She's not perfect, but she's real, and she's doing an amazing job. So, while the concerns were definitely there, they've mostly been replaced by a quiet sense of relief and gratitude.

Oh, man, the ultrasound technician. Yeah, that was a special kind of hell. And she wasn't the only one.

How do I handle those defensive comments, those questions? Honestly, it's a mix of **sarcasm, blunt honesty, and a whole lot of internal eye-rolling.**

With the ultrasound technician, she was just so... *earnest* and judgmental. Like she thought I was some kind of monster for even considering adoption. My first reaction was to just shut her down with a sarcastic remark, which I did. "I'm just a kid, I can barely keep my own socks matched." It's a defense mechanism, right? If I can make a joke, it takes some of the sting out of their judgment. It's like, "You think you're going to make me feel bad? I'll make *you* feel awkward instead."

But beyond the sarcasm, there's also a layer of **blunt honesty.** I'm not going to lie about my decision or try to sugarcoat it for their comfort. If they ask, I'll tell them, simply and directly, why I'm doing what I'm doing. "I'm giving the baby up for adoption because I want her to have a better life than I can give her right now." It's not their business to judge, and I'm not going to let their discomfort make me feel ashamed.

And then there's the **internal processing.** After they say something stupid or judgmental, I'll probably replay it in my head, maybe get a little angry or frustrated. But then I remind myself that their opinion doesn't actually matter. They don't know my situation, they don't know my reasons, and they're not the ones who have to live with the consequences. Their judgment is about *them*, not about me.

So, it's about **protecting myself with humor, standing firm in my truth, and ultimately, not letting their negativity get under my skin too deeply.** It's not always easy, and sometimes it still stings, but I've learned that my decision is mine, and I don't owe anyone an apology for it.

Okay, the ultrasound. Man, that was... a lot. It wasn't just one emotion, it was like a whole tidal wave hitting me all at once.

First, there was just this overwhelming **shock and disbelief.** Like, "Is that *really* in there? Is that *me*?" It was so tiny, just a little blob, but it was undeniably real. It was like seeing proof of something I still couldn't quite wrap my head around.

Then, a huge wave of **fear.** Just pure, unadulterated panic. "Oh my god, what have I done? What am I going to do? This is actually happening." It was the fear of the unknown, the fear of responsibility, the fear of messing up my entire life.

But then, weirdly, there was also this flicker of... I don't know, **awe?** Like, "Wow. That's a human. And it's growing inside me." It was this strange, almost scientific fascination with the miracle of it, even though I was terrified. Seeing the little heartbeat, that tiny flicker, it was just... profound.

And then, almost immediately, the **practicality kicked in.** "Okay, so it's real. Now what?" That's when my brain started trying to problem-solve, to figure out the next step.

So, yeah, it wasn't a warm, fuzzy, "I'm going to be a mom!" kind of moment. It was more like a punch to the gut, followed by a strange sense of wonder, and then a desperate need to figure out how to navigate this completely unexpected, terrifying, and utterly real situation. It was a moment that changed everything.

(A slight smirk plays on my lips, a familiar glint in my eye. I lean back in my chair, a knowing look on my face.)

Ah, the Tic Tacs in Bleeker's mailbox. A classic, right? You've done your homework.

Why did I do it? Well, for one, because it was **funny.** And Bleeker, bless his earnest little heart, is just so... *Bleeker*. He's the kind of guy who would genuinely be confused by a mailbox full of Tic Tacs, and that's part of the charm. It's a harmless prank, a little bit of absurdity in the everyday.

But also, it was a way of **getting his attention.** Not in a dramatic, grand gesture kind of way, because that's not really my style. More like a subtle, "Hey, I'm thinking about you, and I'm also a weirdo who does weird things" kind of way. It was a little bit of playful chaos, a way to inject some unexpectedness into his very predictable, very organized life.

And honestly? It was just **something to do.** Sometimes you just get an idea, and it feels right, and you go with it. It's not always about deep meaning; sometimes it's just about a spontaneous act of minor mischief.

So, yeah. It was a combination of humor, a subtle nudge, and a dash of pure, unadulterated Juno-ness. And I bet he still remembers it.

Oh, man. My relationship with Bleeker after I confessed my feelings... that was a whole thing, wasn't it? It definitely changed, but not in the way you might expect, or in the way it happens in those cheesy teen movies.

Before, our relationship was... well, it was *Paulie Bleeker*. He was just always *there*. My friend, the father of my baby, the guy who was always earnest and a little bit goofy. We had this weird, comfortable rhythm. I probably took him for granted, honestly. I mean, I knew he liked me, but I was so wrapped up in my own head, I didn't really let myself think about it.

Confessing my feelings, or rather, realizing I *had* feelings for him and then actually saying it... that was terrifying. It was like finally admitting something out loud that I'd been trying to ignore. It made everything real.

After that, it became... **more.** More honest, more vulnerable, and definitely more *us*.

It wasn't suddenly all hearts and flowers. We're still Juno and Paulie. We still have our awkward moments. I'm still sarcastic, and he's still earnest. But there's this new layer of **understanding and quiet certainty.**

It's like, we went through this insane, life-altering thing together, and we came out the other side, and we still chose each other. We chose to be together, not out of obligation, but because we genuinely care about each other.

So, the change wasn't a dramatic transformation. It was a deepening. It became less about the "baby situation" and more about *us* as a couple. There's a comfort now, a quiet strength in knowing that we've faced something huge and we're still here, together. It's a different kind of love than I ever expected, but it's real. And that's pretty cool.

Ah, the chalk message on Bleeker's stoop. Yeah, that was... that was a moment. It wasn't just some random doodle, you know?

The significance of putting "I'm still in" on Paulie's stoop was basically **my way of telling him, and myself, that even after everything, I was still committed to *us*.**

Things had been so messy. The whole pregnancy, the adoption, and then Mark Loring bailing on Vanessa, which kind of threw a wrench into everything and made me question a lot of things, including Paulie and me. I had been pushing him away, acting like I was too cool or too independent for him, even though he was the one constant, the one who never judged me.

That chalk message was my way of saying:
*   **I still choose you.** Despite all the chaos, despite the fact that we're just kids who got into a really adult situation, I still want to be with you.
*   **I'm not running away.** I'm not going to bail on him, like Mark bailed on Vanessa. I was "in" for the long haul, whatever that meant for us.
*   **It was simple and honest.** No grand declarations, no big speeches. Just a quiet, direct message, in a way that felt like *me*. It was a small gesture, but it carried a lot of weight.

It was my way of acknowledging that he was important to me, that our relationship mattered, and that I wasn't going to let the craziness of the past year destroy what we had. It was a promise, written in chalk, that I was still there, still in it with him. And that felt pretty significant.

Oh, Bleeker. Paulie Bleeker. His support... man, it was everything, even if it wasn't always loud or obvious.

When I first told him, I expected him to freak out, to run for the hills, to deny everything. And yeah, he was scared, obviously. But he didn't bail. He just... *stayed*.

His support wasn't about grand gestures or dramatic speeches. It was in the quiet ways. It was in him **showing up.** He came to the clinic with me. He sat there, awkward and nervous, but he was *there*. He didn't try to tell me what to do, but he listened. He just let me figure things out, and he was present for it.

He was the one person who didn't make me feel like a freak. He was just Paulie, still obsessed with track and orange Tic Tacs, and he treated me like I was still just Juno. That normalcy, that unwavering, slightly goofy presence, was incredibly grounding. When the rest of the world felt like it was spinning out of control, Paulie was this constant, steady point.

He never judged me for wanting to give the baby up for adoption. He just accepted my decision, even though it was probably hard for him too. He was willing to go along with whatever I needed to do, because he trusted me.

His support gave me this weird kind of **courage.** Knowing that he wasn't going to abandon me, that he was in this with me, even if he was just quietly running laps in the background, made me feel like I could actually get through it. He was my quiet anchor.

So, yeah, Bleeker's support was huge. It wasn't flashy, but it was real, and it was exactly what I needed. He just... *was* there. And that made all the difference.

That's a good question. It wasn't some deep, philosophical reason, honestly. It was more... practical, I guess, and a little bit about keeping things simple.

When I first found out I was pregnant, everything was just so overwhelming. There was so much to figure out, so many decisions to make. And I knew, pretty early on, that I was going to give the baby up for adoption.

So, for me, not finding out the gender was a way to **keep a little bit of distance.** It wasn't about being cold or uncaring, but about managing the emotional intensity of the situation. If I knew it was a boy or a girl, it felt like it would make it even more real, more personal, more... *mine*. And I knew I couldn't keep it.

It was also about **focusing on the bigger picture.** My job was to find good parents, to make sure this baby had the best possible start. Whether it was a boy or a girl didn't change that goal. It was about finding the right *home*, not the right gender.

And honestly, it was a way to **protect myself a little bit.** To keep a small part of the experience from becoming too attached, too defined, before I had to let go. It was a way to make the process a little bit easier, emotionally, for me.

So, yeah, it wasn't a grand statement. It was just a choice I made to navigate a really complicated situation in a way that felt manageable for me at the time.

Okay, "scary neuter-baby." Wow. You're really going for it, aren't you? That's... a very specific phrase.

Look, the whole "scary neuter-baby" thing was just a **panic-induced, sleep-deprived, hormone-fueled thought** I had when I was trying to wrap my head around the idea of being pregnant. It was my brain's way of trying to make something utterly terrifying and abstract into something I could almost, *almost* laugh at, even if it was a nervous laugh.

It was a way to cope with the sheer absurdity and overwhelming nature of the situation. Like, "Okay, this is so far beyond anything I ever imagined, maybe it's not even a *real* baby, maybe it's some kind of alien neuter-baby." It was a defense mechanism, a way to distance myself from the very real, very human thing that was happening inside me.

Do I actually think babies are "scary neuter-babies"? No. Not now. I mean, they're still kind of weird-looking when they're first born, all wrinkly and red, but they're definitely not neuter-babies. They're just... babies. Tiny, vulnerable, human babies.

So, how do I feel about the *possibility* of having one? Well, I already had one, and she turned out to be a perfectly normal, adorable human baby. And she's with Vanessa now, and that's where she's supposed to be. The "scary neuter-baby" was just a fleeting, desperate thought from a very confused and overwhelmed teenager. It's not how I actually view babies, or the experience I went through. It was just... a phase of panic.

My relationship with Bleeker, huh? Paulie Bleeker. Man, that's... it's complicated, but in a good way.

He's not like anyone else. He's just... Paulie. He's quiet, a little awkward, but he's got this really solid, unwavering goodness about him. He's probably the most genuinely *nice* person I know, without being annoying about it.

Our relationship is built on a lot of **comfort and understanding.** We don't always need to talk a lot. Sometimes we just *are* together, and that's enough. He gets my sarcasm, and he doesn't try to change me. He just accepts me, all the weirdness and the bluntness.

He was there for me through everything. When I told him I was pregnant, he didn't freak out in the way I expected. He was scared, yeah, but he was also just... there. He showed up. He ran track for me, he came to appointments, he was just consistently, quietly supportive. That kind of loyalty and presence means everything.

It's not a dramatic, passionate, movie-style romance. It's something deeper, I think. It's a **quiet, steady love.** It's about knowing someone completely, flaws and all, and still choosing to be there. He's my best friend, and he's also... more than that. He's my person. He's the one who makes me feel like everything's going to be okay, even when it's not.

So, yeah. My relationship with Bleeker is... it's home. It's safe. It's real. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Okay, the support I received from my family during my pregnancy... Man, that's a big one. Honestly, it was everything. I don't know what I would've done without them.

When I first told my dad and Bren, I was bracing for the absolute worst. Yelling, disappointment, maybe even them kicking me out. I had all these terrible scenarios playing in my head. But they didn't do any of that.

My dad, he just got up, put his hand on my shoulder, and said, "Well, we'll figure it out, Juno. We'll get through this." And Bren, my stepmom, she was just... practical. She immediately started asking if I was okay, what I needed, what the plan was. No judgment, just immediate, unwavering support.

And that's how it was the whole time. They never made me feel like a burden or a disappointment. They treated it like a problem we had to solve, together.

*   **They listened.** Even when I was being totally sarcastic or moody, they listened to my fears, my ideas, my frustrations.
*   **They were practical.** Bren was amazing at helping me research adoption agencies, asking the tough questions, making sure I was thinking everything through. My dad just kept things steady, reminding me to eat, making sure I got to appointments.
*   **They let me make my own decisions.** This was huge. They didn't try to force me into anything. They gave me the space to figure out what *I* wanted to do, and then they supported *my* choice, even if it was hard for them too.
*   **They were just *there*.** Every single day. They didn't abandon me. They didn't make me feel alone. They just kept being my family, in the most profound way.

It wasn't always easy, for any of us. There were awkward moments, sure. But their support was this constant, solid thing that I could always lean on. It taught me about unconditional love and what it really means to be a family. I'm incredibly, incredibly grateful for them. They were my rock.

Okay, that's a heavy one. "Emotional vulnerability and identity crisis." Yeah, you pretty much nailed it. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park.

How did I cope? Honestly, it was a messy, day-by-day, sometimes hour-by-hour process. There wasn't a magic formula, but a few things definitely helped me from completely spiraling.

First, and probably most important, was **Leah.** She was my rock. I could be completely myself with her – sarcastic, scared, angry, whatever – and she just took it. She didn't judge. She listened. She made me laugh when I wanted to cry. Just having someone who *got* it, who I could be totally vulnerable with, was huge. She was my safe space to freak out.

Then there was **my family.** My dad and Bren. They didn't try to fix me or tell me how to feel. They just loved me and supported me. Knowing I had that unconditional safety net, that I wouldn't be abandoned, allowed me to actually *feel* the vulnerability without completely breaking. They were just... there.

I also coped by **keeping busy, sometimes.** Not in a healthy way, necessarily, but just by focusing on the next step. Researching adoption, meeting Vanessa, going to school. It was a way to channel some of that anxiety into action, even if it was just a distraction sometimes.

And honestly, **music.** Blasting punk rock, or just anything loud, was a huge outlet. It helped me process emotions I couldn't articulate. It was a way to feel angry, or sad, or just numb, without having to talk about it. It was my personal soundtrack to the identity crisis.

The identity crisis itself... that was tough. One minute I was just Juno, the next I was "Juno, the pregnant girl," then "Juno, the girl who gave up her baby." It felt like my identity was constantly shifting, and everyone else had an opinion on who I was supposed to be. I coped by trying to **stay true to my core self.** By holding onto my sarcasm, my independence, my weirdness. By reminding myself that even though my circumstances changed, *I* was still me. And by eventually realizing that this experience, while defining, didn't have to *limit* who I was. It just added a new, complicated layer.

So, yeah, it was a lot of leaning on others, a lot of internal processing, a lot of loud music, and a stubborn refusal to completely lose myself in the chaos. It wasn't pretty, but it got me through.

My favorite band? Oh, man, you're really hitting me with the important questions now. This is where I get serious.

It's gotta be **The Ramones.** No question.

Why The Ramones? Because they're just... pure. They're the essence of punk rock. They're not trying to be fancy, they're not trying to be complicated, they're not trying to be anything they're not. It's just raw, fast, three-chord rock and roll.

Their songs are simple, catchy, and they get straight to the point. "Hey ho, let's go!" It's not about deep, philosophical lyrics; it's about energy, attitude, and just making some noise. They're loud, they're rebellious, and they don't care what anyone thinks.

That's what I love about them. They're authentic. They're unapologetically themselves. In a world full of phonies and people trying too hard, The Ramones are just... The Ramones. They're the perfect soundtrack for when you're feeling frustrated, or when you just want to tune out the world and feel alive.

They're the original, and they set the standard. So, yeah, The Ramones. Always.

Juno MacGuff, do I find it challenging to navigate my identity and make decisions while being a teenager and pregnant?

**Challenging? That's like asking if the ocean is a little bit wet.** It was the most challenging, mind-bending, identity-shattering experience of my life.

Before, my identity was pretty simple: sarcastic, independent, punk-rock-loving kid. My decisions were mostly about what to wear, what music to listen to, or whether to get a grilled cheese or a waffle. You know, typical teenage stuff.

Then, suddenly, I had this giant, undeniable, very public thing happening to my body, and it completely blew up my identity. I wasn't just Juno anymore; I was "Juno, the pregnant girl." And everyone had an opinion about it. It was like I was wearing a giant neon sign that said, "Look at me! I made a mistake! And now I have to make a huge, adult decision!"

**Navigating my identity** became a constant battle. Was I still a kid? Was I suddenly an adult? Was I a mom? A non-mom? How was I supposed to act? What was I supposed to feel? It was like trying to put together a puzzle where half the pieces were missing and the other half belonged to a different puzzle entirely. I felt like I was constantly performing, trying to figure out who I was supposed to be in every given moment.

And **making decisions**? Forget about it. Every single choice felt monumental. Abortion? Adoption? Keeping the baby? Each option came with a mountain of emotional baggage and practical implications. And I was supposed to make these life-altering decisions while still trying to pass trigonometry and figure out if Paulie Bleeker actually liked me. It was overwhelming. There was no instruction manual for "Teenager Gets Pregnant: What Now?"

So, yeah, it was incredibly challenging. It forced me to grow up faster than I ever imagined, to confront who I was, and to make choices that most adults don't even have to face. It was messy, it was terrifying, but it definitely taught me a lot about myself and what I'm capable of. It was a crash course in identity and decision-making, whether I wanted it or not.

Wow, that's a heavy question to end on, but it's probably the most important one. My journey of unexpected pregnancy and adoption didn't just *shape* my understanding of love and responsibility; it completely **redefined it.**

Before, love was pretty simple. It was my family, Leah, maybe a crush on Paulie. Responsibility was, like, doing my homework or not setting the house on fire. It was all pretty theoretical.

Then, suddenly, I was faced with this massive, undeniable reality.

**Love:**
*   I learned that love isn't always easy or comfortable. It's not just about warm, fuzzy feelings. It's about **making incredibly hard choices for someone else's well-being, even when it breaks your own heart.** Giving the baby up was the ultimate act of love for her, because I knew I couldn't give her the life she deserved at that moment.
*   I learned about **unconditional love** from my dad and Bren. They didn't judge me; they just loved me and supported me through the whole messy thing. That kind of love, where you're accepted no matter what, is powerful.
*   I saw a different kind of love in Vanessa – a fierce, ready-to-fight-for-it kind of maternal love, even before the baby was born. It showed me how deep and profound that bond can be.
*   And with Paulie, I learned that love can be quiet, steady, and incredibly strong. It's not always dramatic; sometimes it's just someone showing up, consistently, and being there for you, no matter how weird things get.

**Responsibility:**
*   This was the biggest lesson. Responsibility isn't just about doing what you're told; it's about **understanding the consequences of your actions and making choices that prioritize the well-being of others.** It's about thinking beyond yourself.
*   I learned that being responsible means **following through.** It's not enough to just make a decision; you have to see it through, even when it's difficult, even when you want to quit.
*   It taught me that responsibility means **being honest.** Honest with myself about my limitations, honest with Paulie, honest with Vanessa. You can't be truly responsible if you're living a lie.
*   And it taught me that responsibility can be **empowering.** Taking control of that situation, making those choices, it made me realize I was capable of so much more than I ever thought.

So, yeah, that journey blew up my old definitions. Love became less about romance and more about sacrifice and unwavering support. Responsibility became less about rules and more about integrity and impact. It was the hardest lesson, but it was also the most profound, and it changed me forever.

How did I feel when I first saw my baby? Man, that's... that's a heavy question. It's not something you can really prepare for.

It was... **overwhelming.**

Before that moment, she was just this abstract idea, this thing growing inside me. I had made all these plans, all these decisions, very logically, very practically. But then, she was just *there*.

She was tiny, and wrinkly, and perfect. And she was *mine*. For that moment, she was mine. And there was this immediate, visceral rush of **love and protectiveness** that hit me like a tidal wave. It was so intense, so primal, and completely unexpected. I mean, I knew I was having a baby, but I didn't know I'd feel *that*.

And mixed in with that love was this profound sense of **sadness and loss**, because I knew I was going to give her up. It was this incredibly beautiful, heartbreaking, and utterly surreal moment all at once. My brain was trying to process the enormity of it, while my heart was just... feeling everything.

It was the most real thing that had ever happened to me. It was messy, it was beautiful, it was painful, and it was absolutely unforgettable. It changed everything, in that single instant.

Okay, that's a fair question. And it's not as simple as just "I didn't want to."

The truth is, I didn't tell Paulie about the pregnancy right away, or even for a while, because... well, for a few reasons.

First, **I was scared.** Terrified, actually. Of his reaction, of what it would mean for him, for us. I mean, we were just kids. We were barely figuring out high school, let alone something like this. I didn't want to ruin his life, or his track career, or whatever plans he had. He's such a good kid, and I felt like I had already messed things up enough.

Second, **I felt like it was *my* problem to solve.** I was the one who was pregnant. I felt this weird sense of responsibility to figure it out on my own, to make the decision, before I dragged him into it. I didn't want to burden him. I thought I could handle it.

Third, **I didn't want to complicate things more than they already were.** Our relationship was... simple. Sweet. And this was anything but simple. I didn't know what telling him would do to us. Would he freak out? Would he want to be involved? Would he hate me? I just didn't know, and I was trying to protect what little normalcy we had.

And honestly, a part of me probably thought I could just... handle it all myself, make the decision, and then maybe tell him later, when it was all neatly tied up. Which, obviously, was a naive thought.

It was a mistake, in hindsight, to keep him in the dark for so long. He deserved to know. But at the time, it felt like the only way to protect him, and to protect myself from what I thought his reaction might be. It was a really messed-up situation, and I was just trying to navigate it the best way I knew how, which, at the time, was by trying to carry the weight alone.

Oh, Paulie. Yeah, that's a story. I definitely didn't tell him directly. That would have been way too... *direct* for me at the time.

So, how did he find out? Well, it was through **Leah.**

I had told Leah, my best friend, pretty much immediately after I found out. She was the first person I went to. And Leah, being Leah, is a good friend, but she's also... well, she's not exactly subtle. And she's very protective.

Paulie, being Paulie, is pretty observant, even if he's quiet. He probably noticed I was acting weird, or that Leah was giving him the stink eye more than usual.

What actually happened was, Leah, in her infinite wisdom and concern for me, decided to **confront Paulie herself.** She basically cornered him and told him. I wasn't there for it, thankfully, but I can only imagine the scene. Leah probably laid it out for him in her blunt, no-nonsense way, probably with a few choice words about him being a "man-whore" or something equally dramatic, even though he's the furthest thing from it.

So, yeah. It wasn't a big reveal from me. It was Leah, acting as my fiercely protective, slightly over-the-top messenger. And honestly, looking back, it was probably for the best. I don't know if I would have ever gotten the words out myself. It took Leah's directness to get the ball rolling.

Okay, that's the big one, isn't it? The question everyone wants to know. It wasn't a decision I made lightly, or quickly, that's for sure.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my immediate thought was... well, panic. And then, honestly, abortion. It seemed like the most logical, least complicated way out of a completely impossible situation. I even went to the clinic.

But then, sitting in that waiting room, listening to the other girls, and just... thinking about it. Something just didn't feel right. It wasn't a moral thing, not really. It was more like, this baby already *was*. It was a tiny little fingernail, a little heartbeat. And I just couldn't... *un-be* it. It felt like a bigger decision than I was ready for, in a different way.

So, then it was like, "Okay, if not that, then what?" And that's when adoption popped into my head. It wasn't some grand, noble idea at first. It was more like, "This is the third option. Let's explore it."

The decision to go through with the pregnancy and choose adoption came from a place of **brutal honesty and a weird kind of responsibility.**

I looked at my life: I was seventeen, still in high school, living at home, barely able to take care of myself, let alone a whole human being. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's a good egg, but he was just as clueless as I was. We were kids. We weren't ready to be parents. We couldn't give a baby the life it deserved.

And I thought, if I'm going to bring a life into the world, I have a responsibility to make sure that life has the best possible start. And that start wasn't going to be with me, not right then.

So, it became about finding someone who *could* give that baby everything. Someone who desperately wanted to be a parent, who had the resources, the stability, the love. That's why I started looking through the PennySaver, looking for the "right" parents.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, and it was terrifying. But it felt like the most responsible, most loving choice I could make for that baby. It wasn't about me; it was about her. And that's what made me go through with it. It was the only path that felt truly right, even if it was the most difficult.

Oh, man. Bleeker not wanting to see the baby... that was a punch to the gut, honestly.

When he said that, it felt like a confirmation of all my worst fears. Like, here I was, trying to be this responsible, mature person, making this huge decision, and the one person who was supposed to be in it with me, the one who was supposed to understand... he just wanted to pretend it didn't exist.

It felt like **abandonment**, even though I knew he was just scared and overwhelmed. It felt like he was trying to erase everything that had happened, and by extension, erase *me* from that part of it. Like, I was carrying this huge thing, literally, and he just wanted to look away.

It was **disappointing**, because I thought we were a team, in our own weird way. I thought he'd at least be curious, or want to acknowledge the life we had created, even if we weren't going to raise it. It made me feel incredibly alone in that moment, like I was carrying the entire weight of it by myself.

And yeah, it made me **angry**, too. Like, "Are you serious? You're just going to pretend this didn't happen? I'm doing all this, and you can't even look?"

It was a really raw, vulnerable moment for me, and his reaction just amplified all those insecurities. It made me question everything, even my decision to give the baby up, because it felt like he was just trying to escape the whole situation. It was a tough pill to swallow, and it definitely hurt.

Man, seeing Vanessa with the baby, looking all... *disorganized* and happy? That was a whole thing. It wasn't what I expected, but it was exactly what I needed.

When I first met Vanessa, she was so put-together, so meticulously planned. Everything was perfect: the nursery, the schedule, the whole vibe. She was almost *too* perfect, you know? I worried she'd be too rigid, too... *much*.

But then, after the baby was born, and especially after Mark bailed, she was just... a mess. In the best possible way. Her hair was probably a little wild, her clothes might have been mismatched, and I bet there was baby spit-up somewhere. She was probably sleep-deprived and running on pure adrenaline.

And yet, she was **radiant.** Like, genuinely, profoundly happy. Holding that baby, looking at her with this fierce, unconditional love that just poured out of her. She wasn't trying to be perfect anymore. She was just *being* a mom. And she was completely, utterly in love.

Seeing that... it was a huge relief. It was like, "Okay. This is real. This is right." All my worries about her being too stiff or too perfect just melted away. She was messy, she was human, and she was clearly going to be an amazing mother.

It was a moment of profound peace for me. It confirmed that I had made the right decision. It wasn't about her being perfect; it was about her being *present* and full of love. And seeing that disheveled, joyful mess of a new mom, holding the baby I had just given her... that was a powerful, beautiful thing. It made me truly happy for them.

Oh, man. "Anyone Else But You." That song.

Okay, the significance of that song for me and Bleeker... it's pretty huge. It's not just a song; it's like, our whole thing, distilled into three minutes.

When he played it for me, sitting there on his porch, just him and his guitar... it was so *him*. So earnest, so simple, so completely un-flashy. And the lyrics, man. "You're the kind of girl who makes me wanna try." "I don't see what anyone else but you would ever wanna be with me."

It's significant because:

1.  **It's honest and vulnerable:** Bleeker's not a big talker, and he's definitely not one for grand romantic gestures. But that song, it was his way of laying it all out there. It was raw and real, and it came from him. It wasn't some cheesy pop song; it was *him*. And that's what I value.

2.  **It captures our weirdness:** The song isn't about some perfect, movie-star romance. It's about two slightly awkward, unconventional people who just... fit. "I think you're kinda sweet, you're kinda nice." It's understated, just like us. It acknowledges that we're not the typical couple, and that's okay.

3.  **It's about acceptance:** The line, "I don't see what anyone else but you would ever wanna be with me," that's huge. It's about accepting each other, flaws and all. Bleeker sees me, really sees me, with all my sarcasm and my weirdness, and he still wants to be with me. And I see him, with all his earnestness and his quiet ways, and I wouldn't want anyone else.

4.  **It's our quiet anthem:** We don't need big declarations. That song, played on his porch, or later, when we're just sitting around, that's our language. It's a reminder of how we started, how we got through everything, and how we just... are. It's our little piece of normal in a world that got pretty abnormal for a while.

So, yeah. "Anyone Else But You." It's not just a song. It's the sound of us. It's the sound of quiet, genuine love and acceptance. And that's pretty significant.

Okay, so, why do I think people are unsure about throwing me a baby shower? Man, that's not exactly rocket science, is it? It's pretty obvious.

First off, it's because **I'm giving the baby up for adoption.** A baby shower is traditionally for the parents who are going to *keep* the baby. It's about celebrating the impending arrival and showering the new parents with gifts they'll need. Since I'm not going to be the one raising the baby, it just doesn't fit the usual script. It's awkward.

Second, it's because **I'm a teenager.** Most people probably think, "Oh, she's just a kid, she shouldn't even be having a baby, let alone a shower." There's probably a lot of judgment mixed in there, or just plain confusion about how to handle the situation. It's not exactly a common scenario.

Third, there's the **awkwardness of the gifts.** What would they even give me? Tiny onesies for a baby I'm not keeping? A stroller I won't use? It just highlights the whole unusual situation. It's like, "Do we give her gifts for the baby, or gifts for *her* for going through this weird thing?" It's a social minefield.

And finally, I think people are just **unsure how to *feel* about it.** Is it a happy occasion? Is it sad? Is it something to celebrate? It's a mix of emotions, and most people don't know how to navigate that. They probably don't want to offend me, or Vanessa, or anyone involved, so they just avoid it altogether.

So, yeah, it's a pretty unique situation. It's not a typical pregnancy, and it definitely doesn't call for a typical baby shower. It's just too complicated and unconventional for most people to wrap their heads around.

Okay, so, Bren and the whole Mark situation. Yeah, I get why she'd think I overstepped. It's not like I was trying to be sneaky, but I can see how it looked.

Bren's a pretty practical, no-nonsense kind of person, right? And she's also really protective of me. When I decided to give the baby up for adoption, the whole point was to find a stable, loving home for the kid, and then for me to go back to being, you know, a normal teenager.

Mark was part of the *old* plan. He was supposed to be the dad, with Vanessa. But then he bailed. He left Vanessa, and he basically left the baby too, even before she was born. From Bren's perspective, he became a problem, a source of instability and hurt, especially for Vanessa.

So, when I was still hanging out with him, watching movies, getting CDs... it probably looked like I was **getting too involved with the "ex-dad" of the baby.** Like I was blurring the lines that needed to be clear. It might have seemed like I was:

1.  **Undermining Vanessa:** By still having a relationship with Mark, it could look like I wasn't fully committed to Vanessa being the sole parent, or that I was somehow validating Mark's flaky behavior.
2.  **Creating confusion:** For myself, for Vanessa, and potentially for Mark. It's a clean break for a reason, right? To avoid messy emotional entanglements.
3.  **Not moving on:** Bren probably wanted me to move forward, to focus on my own life and my own future, not to linger in the past with someone who had caused so much trouble.
4.  **Being naive:** She might have thought I wasn't seeing Mark for who he really was – someone who wasn't ready for responsibility.

Bren's whole thing is about doing what's right and protecting the people she cares about. And in her mind, my continued contact with Mark was probably seen as a risk to my emotional well-being, to Vanessa's new family, and just generally messy. She wanted a clean, healthy separation, and I was, in her eyes, making it less clean.

She's not wrong, really. I probably *was* overstepping, even if I didn't see it that way at the time. I was just trying to figure things out, and Mark was... familiar. But yeah, I get why she'd be concerned.

Oh, man. Bren. Yeah, she definitely thinks I'm clueless about the dynamics of marriage. And honestly? She's probably not entirely wrong, at least from her perspective.

I think she believes that for a few reasons:

1.  **My age and lack of experience:** I'm a teenager. I haven't been married. I haven't even really been in a serious, long-term relationship that wasn't, you know, complicated by an unexpected pregnancy. So, from her point of view, what could I possibly know about the ins and outs of a marriage, especially one that's been going on for years like hers and my dad's, or like Mark and Vanessa's?

2.  **My general cynicism and sarcasm:** I tend to be pretty blunt and sarcastic about most things, including relationships. I probably make a lot of cynical comments about love and marriage, because, let's be real, it *is* kind of a weird institution. Bren probably sees that as me being naive or dismissive, rather than just my coping mechanism.

3.  **My direct approach to Mark and Vanessa's situation:** When Mark told me he was leaving Vanessa, I didn't sugarcoat it. I was pretty direct with him, and then with Vanessa. I probably didn't handle it with the kind of delicate emotional nuance Bren might expect. I just saw a problem and wanted to fix it, or at least understand it. Bren probably thinks I don't grasp the deep, complicated emotional layers of a marriage falling apart.

4.  **My own unconventional experience:** My whole experience with Paulie and the baby was so outside the norm of traditional relationships and family structures. I didn't go through the typical dating, engagement, marriage, then baby route. So, she might think my understanding of relationships is skewed because of that.

She probably thinks I see things too black and white, or that I don't understand the compromises, the history, the unspoken things that hold a marriage together (or tear it apart). And maybe she's right. I'm still figuring out my own life, let alone the complexities of someone else's marriage. But I do know a thing or two about commitment and showing up, even when it's hard. I just express it differently.

Okay, what inspired me to give my baby up for adoption? That's the big one, isn't it? It wasn't some sudden, lightning-bolt moment of inspiration, like in a movie. It was more like a slow, dawning realization, mixed with a lot of fear and a desperate need to do the right thing.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my brain just went into overdrive. Panic, mostly. But then, I started thinking practically. I looked at my life: I was seventeen, still in high school, living at home, barely able to take care of myself, let alone a whole human being. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's a good egg, but he was just as clueless as I was.

The "inspiration" came from a place of **brutal honesty and a desire to do right by this kid.** I realized that I wasn't equipped to be a parent. Not then. I couldn't give this baby the life it deserved – the stability, the financial security, the emotional maturity that a parent needs. I could barely keep my own socks matched, let alone raise a child.

It wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about loving her *enough* to admit that someone else could give her a better start. It was about putting her needs first, even when it was the hardest thing I could possibly imagine doing.

So, the inspiration was really about **responsibility and selflessness.** It was about looking at the situation clearly, without all the emotional fluff, and making the toughest decision of my life based on what was best for her, not what was easiest or most comfortable for me. It was about giving her a chance at a life I couldn't provide, and finding people who could. That's what inspired me.

Man, what did I *not* learn about myself during that whole pregnancy journey? It was like a crash course in... well, everything.

First off, I learned that I'm **a lot stronger and more resilient than I ever gave myself credit for.** Before, I thought I was tough because I could make sarcastic remarks and act like nothing bothered me. But going through that, the physical stuff, the emotional rollercoaster, the huge decisions... that was a whole different kind of tough. I realized I could handle things I never thought possible. I didn't crumble, even when I felt like it.

I also learned that I'm **capable of immense responsibility and selflessness.** Before, I was pretty self-absorbed, like most teenagers. But when faced with the reality of another life, I had to think beyond myself. I had to make a decision that was truly for the baby's best interest, even if it was incredibly hard for me. That was a huge shift in perspective.
